case_name: K.S. Rashid Son v. Income-tax Investigation Commission

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 118 to 121 of 1952 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION CIVIL APPEALS Nos. 118 to 121 of 1952.  Appeals under article 133  1   c

facts.text: Appeals arose from judgment and order dated 10th August 1950 of High Court of Punjab at Simla by Khosla and Kapur JJ.

anchor.surface_text: of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 10th August, 1950, of the High Court of Judicature, Punjab at Simla  Khosla and Kapur JJ.

facts.text: High Court dismissed Civil Miscellaneous Nos. 256, 260, 261 and 262 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: . in Civil Miscellaneous Nos. 256, 260, 261 and 262 of 1950 . Dr. Balkshi Tek Chand  T. N. Sethi, with him  for the appellants.

facts.text: Partnership firm K.S. Rashid & Son started on 5th May 1934 with partners K.S. Rashid Ahmed, Saeed Ahmed, and Mrs. Zafar Muhammed.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that a partnership firm carrying on business under the name and style of K.S. Rashid Son was started on the 5th of May, 1934, the partners being three in number to wit K.S. Rashid Ahmed, Saeed Ahmed, his son, and Mrs. Zafar Muhammed, his mother

facts.text: Mrs. Zafar Muhammed died on 7th January 1946, dissolving the partnership.

anchor.surface_text: Mrs. Zafar Muhammed died on the 7th of January, 1946, and as a result of her death the partnership stood dissolved.

facts.text: New firm K.S. Rashid & Son started on 8th January 1946 with surviving partners and Saeeda Begum.

anchor.surface_text: Immediately on the day following, that is to say on the 8th of January, 1946, a new firm was started bearing the same name, with the two surviving partners of the original firm and one Saeeda Begum, a daughter of K.S. Rashid, as the third partner.

facts.text: Central Government referred cases of firm and individuals to Income-tax Investigation Commission on 31st December 1947 under section 5 of Act XXX of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: On the 31st of December, 71947, the Central Government referred the cases of this firm, as well as of the individuals companystituting it, to the Income-taxInvestigation Commission for enquiry and report under section 5of Act XXX of 1947

facts.text: Authorised official under section 5(4)(3) started income-tax investigation proceedings against appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The authorised official appointed under section 5  4  3  of the Act, who figures as respondent No. 2 in all these appeals, in due companyrse started investigation in these cases

facts.text: Authorised official extended investigations to period subsequent to 31st March 1943, after which income-tax assessments were completed.

anchor.surface_text: and the appellants companyplaint is, that companytrary to the provisions of the Act, he extended his investigations to a period subsequent to the 31st March, 1943, up to which date the income-tax assessment in all these cases was companypleted.

facts.text: Petition complaining about investigation extension made to authorised official on 8th April 1949, no order passed.

anchor.surface_text: A petition embodying this companyplaint was made -to the authorised official on the 8th of April, 1949, but numberorder was passed on the petition, as the Commission was expecting an early change of law in this respect.

facts.text: Law amended by Ordinance dated 5th July 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The law was amended by an Ordinance dated the 5th of July, 1949, but the appellants still companytended that the amendment was neither retrospective

facts.text: Account books shown to official under protest.

anchor.surface_text: The account books, however, were shown to the official under protest.

facts.text: Three applications filed before Commission on 17th September 1949 regarding Mrs. Zafar Muhammed, Saeeda Begum, and new firm.

anchor.surface_text: On the 17th September, 1949, three applications were filed before the Commission, one with regard to the affairs of Mrs. Zafar Muhammed stating that numberinvestigation companyld take place in regard to her as she was already deadthe second with regard to the affairs of Saeeda Begum on the ground that she being a new partner and number having been assessed before, was number subject to the jurisdiction of the Commission while the third application was to the effect that the new firm, which came into existence on the 8th of January, 1946, companyld number have its affairs enquired into at all under the provisions of the Act.

facts.text: Four miscellaneous petitions filed in June 1950 before High Court of Punjab (C.M. Nos. 259 to 262 of 1950) under articles 226 and 227.

anchor.surface_text: After that, in June, 1950, four miscellaneous petitions were filed,  being C.M. Gases Nos. 259 to 262 of 1950  on behalf of the appellants, before the High Court of Punjab

facts.text: Petitions prayed for writ of prohibition against Commission and official proceeding with investigations under s.5 Act XXX 1947.

anchor.surface_text: and the prayers made therein were of a three- fold character. It was prayed in the first place that a writ of prohibition might be issued to the Commission and the authorised official directing them number to proceed with the investigation

facts.text: Petitions prayed for writ of certiorari quashing proceedings already commenced.

anchor.surface_text: The second prayer was for a writ in the nature of certiorari for quashing the proceedings already companymenced.

facts.text: Alternative prayer for revision under article 227.

anchor.surface_text: The third and the alternative claim was that the proceedings before the Commission might be revised under article 277 of the Constitution

facts.text: Rules issued by High Court on 25th July 1950 after report from Investigation Commission.

anchor.surface_text: Upon these petitions, rules were issued on the 25th of July, 1950, after a report from the Investigation Commission had been called for.

facts.text: Respondents contended Punjab High Court lacked jurisdiction as assessees belong to Punjab and Commission in Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondents, who resisted these petitions, certain preliminary points were raised in bar of the petitioners claim. It was companytended in the first place that the petitioners being assessees belonging to P., their assessments were to be made by the Income-tax Commissioner of that State

facts.text: Respondents contended remedies under Act XXX 1947 are exclusive, articles 226/227 not available.

anchor.surface_text: The second objection was that the Act itself being of a special nature which created new rights and liabilities, the remedies provided for in the Act itself for any breach or violation thereof were the only remedies

facts.text: Respondents contended sections 5(3) and 9 of Act XXX 1947 bar relief.

anchor.surface_text: The third ground taken was that the companyrt companyld number give relief to the petitioners because of sections 5 3  and 9 of Act XXX of 1947.

facts.text: High Court dismissed petitions on first two grounds.

anchor.surface_text: These companytentions found favour with the learned Judges who heard the petitions, and although they did number express any final opinion on the third point raised they dismissed the applications of the petitioners on the first two grounds

facts.text: Appellants availed remedy under section 8(5) of Act, reference made to High Court of Allahabad awaiting decision.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the present case is companycerned, it has been brought to our numberice that the appellants before us have already availed themselves of the remedy provided for in section 8 5  of the Investigation Commission Act and that a reference has been made to the High Court of Allahabad

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on January 22, 1954 by Mukherjea J.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. January, 22. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MUKHERJEA J.--These four companysolidated appeals

facts.text: Supreme Court held Punjab High Court had jurisdiction under article 226.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, the first companytention raised by Dr. Tek Chand must be accepted as sound and the view taken by the Punjab High Court on the question of jurisdiction cannot be sustained.

issues.text: whether the Punjab High Court had jurisdiction under article 226 of the Constitution to issue writs of certiorari or prohibition against the Income-tax Investigation Commission located in Delhi

anchor.surface_text: So far as the first, point is concerned, which relates to the question of jurisdiction of the Punjab High Court to issue writs of certiorari or prohibition in these cases, the learned Judges based their decision entirely upon the pronouncement of the Judicial Committee in the well known case of Ryots of Garabandho v. Zamindar of Parlakimedi

issues.text: whether the remedy provided under section 8(5) of the Income-tax Investigation Commission Act, 1947 is the exclusive remedy excluding the jurisdiction under articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: So far as the second point is concerned, the High Court relies upon the ordinary rule of construction that where the legislature has passed a new statute giving a new remedy, that remedy is the only one which could be pursued.

anchor.surface_text: the court could not give relief to the petitioners because of sections 5 3 and 9 of Act XXX of 1947. anchor.surface_text: The Constitution introduced a fundamental change of law in this respect. As has been explained by this Court in the case referred to above, while article 225 of the Constitution preserves to the existing High Courts the powers and jurisdictions which they had previously, article 226 confers, on all the High Courts, new and very wide powers

precedents.citation: Ryots of Garabandho v. Zamindar of Parlakitnedi 1

anchor.surface_text: Ryots of Garabandho v. Zamindar of Parlakitnedi 1 . The question for companysideration in that case was, whether the High Court of Madras had jurisdiction to issue a writ of certiorari in respect of an order passed by the Collective Board of Revenue, as an appellate authority, in certain proceedings for settlement of rent between the Zamindar of Parlakimedi and the Ryots of certain villages within his estate situated in the district of Ganjam which was wholly outside the limits of the Presidency town of Madras.

precedents.case_name: Ryots of Garabandho v. Zamindar of Parlakimedi
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court of Madras lacked jurisdiction to issue certiorari against Board of Revenue for rent settlement in Ganjam district outside its limits

precedents.citation: Nundo Lal Bose v. The Calcutta Corporation 1

anchor.surface_text: Nundo Lal Bose v. The Calcutta Corporation 1 , where a certiorari was issued by the Calcutta High Court to quash an assessment made by the Commissioners of the town of Calcutta on a certain dwelling house. This contention was repelled by the Judicial Committee with the following observations The question is whether the principle of that case can be applied in the present case to the settlement of rent for land in Ganjam, merely on the basis of the location of the Board of Revenue, as a body which is ordinarily resident or located within the town of Madras, or on the basis that the order complained of was made within the town.

precedents.case_name: Nundo Lal Bose v. The Calcutta Corporation
precedents.cited_proposition: Certiorari issued by Calcutta High Court based on location within town for quashing assessment

anchor.surface_text: Election Commission v. Venkata Rao 2   where the observations of the Judicial Committee in Parlakimedis case, upon which reliance has been placed by the Punjab High Court, have been fully explained. It is to be noted first of all, that prior to the commencement of the Constitution the powers of issuing prerogative writs could be exercised in India only by the High Courts of Calcutta,, Madras and Bombay and that also within very rigid and defined limits. The writs could be issued only to the extent that the power in that respect was not taken away by the Codes of Civil and Criminal Procedure 3  and they could be directed only to persons and authorities within the original civil jurisdiction of these High Courts.

precedents.cited_proposition: Explanation of High Courts' jurisdiction to issue writs under Article 226 of the Constitution, wider than pre-Constitution powers
precedents.cited_holding: Article 226 confers new and wide powers on all High Courts to issue writs throughout territories in relation to which they exercise jurisdiction, to persons/authorities amenable within those territories

precedents.citation: Besant v. Tire Advocate General of Madras

anchor.surface_text: Vide in this connection Besant v. Tire Advocate General of Madras. 46 I.A. 176. in the matter of issuing writs which they never possessed before. The makers of the Constitution thus observed Patanjali Sastri C.J. in delivering the judgment of the court, having decided to provide for certain basic safeguards for the people in the new set up, which they called fundamental rights, evidently thought it necessary to provide also a quick and inexpensive remedy for the enforcement of such rights, and, finding that the prerogative writs, which the courts in England had developed and used whenever urgent necessity demanded immediate and decisive interposition, were peculiarly suited for the purpose, they conferred, in the States sphere, new and wide powers on the High Courts of issuing directions, orders, or writs primarily for the enforcement of fundamental rights, the power to issue such directions, etc. for any other purpose being also included with a view apparently to place all the High Courts in this country in somewhat the same position as the Court of Kings Bench in England.

precedents.case_name: Besant v. The Advocate General of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Pre-Constitution powers of High Courts regarding prerogative writs

anchor.surface_text: This line of reasoning does number appear to us to be proper and we do number think that the decision in the Parlakimedis case 1  is really of assistance in determining the question of jurisdiction of the High Courts in the matter of issuing writs under article 226 of the Constitution. The whole law on this subject has been discussed and elucidated by this companrt in its recent pronouncement in Election Commission v. Venkata Rao 2   where the observations of the Judicial Committee in Parlakimedis case, upon which reliance has been placed by the Punjab High Court, have been fully explained.

precedents.case_name: Ryots of Garabandho v. Zamindar of Parlakimedi
precedents.cited_proposition: Decision not really of assistance for Article 226 jurisdiction
